author: m.kalinin
content:
With the recent state of the research, eth1-to-eth2 transition with two-way bridge should be like this:
1. Optional. One-week miners voting.
2. Finality gadget with instant finality scheme.
3. Eth1 is a shard.
4. Optional. Issuance reduction.
5. Swap block production to PoS.
6. Switch Eth1 to stateless client.

Instant finality scheme is described in this write up https://ethresear.ch/t/miners-vote-back/7129

author: m.kalinin
content: Eth1 is a shard is a requirement for Eth1 follow distance reduction. It, actually, one of the ways to achieve that, but looks like the most promising one. Steps 1 and 2 are mostly related to the work being done on Eth1 side.

author: axic3354
content:
Hm, this is a bit confusing to me to be honest. Is the two-way bridge vs. merge really a different avenue? It more seems to be a roadmap.

With the merge it is unclear how we arrive at the merge, that isn't specified, but the above could be a path to the merge.

author: m.kalinin
content:
My recent understanding of the two-way bridge is like it would be a "slow" merge. For example, you may enable finality gadget starting from the first step. It would unlock data availability engine use case with quite a big delay, but anyway it's doable. Then if you want to bring this up to a level of practical finality you'll have to significantly reduce the follow distance on both sides. IMO, the most reasonable way of doing that is to treat Eth1 as a shard and invalidate Eth1 blocks that are not satisfying a number of validity conditions (Instant finality scheme).

Doing all these steps bring us closer to what exactly the merge proposal is. Just need to add a couple of steps and we're there. That's why I've made this high level roadmap. It shows that the two-way bridge at its finish line is very close to the merge from technical point of view.

author: m.kalinin
content:
> Hm, this is a bit confusing to me to be honest. Is the two-way bridge vs. merge really a different avenue? It more seems to be a roadmap.
If to speak strictly about the approaches to two-way bridge, there are two schemes with miners to include finalized checkpoints on chain described in the document above. Yet I haven't explored the idea based on light client proofs brought on Eth1 chain. I am about to do this in the short term. But Isntant finality + attesting to Eth1 as to a shard looks like the most promising scheme.
